chapterTitle: Financial Statements, Taxes, and Cash Flow

columns.text: This exercise requires us to compute the owners' equity, change in net working capital, cash flow from assets and cash flow to creditors.

Let's first define the important terms in the problem.

- **Owners' Equity** represents the residual value of assets minus liabilities.

- **Change in Net Working Capital** means the change in current assets minus the change in current liabilities.

- **Cash Flow from assets** is the total of all cash flows relating to company's assets.

- **Cash Flow to Creditors** is the amount of money that is paid to the debt holders during an accounting period.

We will first compute the total assets for 2017 and 2018.

$$\begin {array}{lrr} 
\text{}&\text{2017}&\text{2018}\\ 
\text{Current assets }&\$\hspace{10pt}\text{1,206} &\$\hspace{10pt}\text{1,307}\\ 
\text{Net fixed assets}&\underline{\text{4,973}} &\underline{\text{5,988}}\\ 
\textbf{Total Assets}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}{6,179}}}}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}{7,295}}}}\\ 
\end{array}

Next, we will calculate the total liabilities for 2017 and 2018.

$$\begin {array}{lrr} 
\text{}&\text{2017}&\text{2018}\\ 
\text{Current Liabilities}&\$\hspace{10pt}\text{482} &\$\hspace{10pt}\text{541}\\ 
\text{Long-term Debt}&\underline{\text{2,628}} &\underline{\text{2,795}}\\ 
\textbf{Total Liabilities}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}{3,110}}}}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}{3,336}}}}\\ 
\end{array}

Now that we have computed the total assets and liabilities, let's now compute for the owner's equity using the equation in step 3.

$$\begin {array}{lrr} 
\text{}&\text{2017}&\text{2018}\\ 
\text{Total Assets}&\$\hspace{10pt}\text{6,179} &\$\hspace{10pt}\text{7,295}\\ 
\text{Total Liabilities}&\underline{\text{(3,110)}} &\underline{\text{(3,336)}}\\ 
\textbf{Owner's Equity}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}{3,069}}}}&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}{3,959}}}}\\ 
\end{array}$$

Therefore, the owners' equity for 2017 and 2018 of Parrothead Enterprises are **$3,069** and **$3,959**, respectively.

### b. Change in Net Working Capital for 2018.

Change in Net Working Capital is computed as follows:

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Change in NWC} &= \text{NWC Ending} -{\text{NWC Beginning}}\\[5pt] 
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

NWC - Net Working Capital

We will now compute the change in net working capital using the formula in step 7.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Change in NWC} &= \text{NWC, 2018} -{\text{NWC, 2017}}\\[5pt] 
&= \text{(CA, 2018 - CL, 2018)} -{\text{(CA, 2017 - CL, 2017)}}\\[5pt] 
&= \text{(\$1,307- 541)} -{\text{(\$1,206- 482)}}\\[5pt] 
&= \text{\$766} - {\text{724}}\\[5pt] 
&= \underline{\underline{\textbf{\$42}}} 
\end{aligned}$$
 
â€‹Therefore, the change in net working capital of Parrothead Enterprises is **$42**.

### C. Fixed Assets Sold and Cash Flow from Assets

To compute for the fixed assets sold, let's first identify the net capital spending of the company as computed below:

$$\begin{aligned} \text{NCS} &= \text{NFA 2018} - {\text{NFA 2017}} + {\text{Depreciation}}\\[5pt] &= \text{5,988} - {\text{4,973}} + {\text{1,363}}\\[5pt] 
&= \underline{\underline{\text{\$2,378}}} 
\end{aligned}$$



Where:

NCS - Net capital spending
NFA - Net Fixed Asset

Then, since the company had a net capital spending of $2,378. We also know that the net capital spending is equal to fixed asset bought less fixed assets sold. Hence, to get the fixed asset sold we will squeeze back the formula:

$$\begin{aligned} 
\text{Fixed Asset Sold} &= \text{Fixed Asset Bought } - {\text{Net Capital Spending}}\\[5pt] 
&= \text{\$2,496 } - {\text{2,378}}\\[5pt] 
&= \underline{\underline{\textbf{\$118}}} 
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the fixed asset sold of Parrothead Enterprises is **$118**.

Next, to compute the cash flow from assets, we must first calculate the operating cash flow. Let's first compute the Net Income of the company using the income statement below:

$$\def\arraystretch{1.2} 
\begin{array}{|c|} \hline 
\textbf{Parrothead Enterprises}\\ 
\text{Income Statement }\\ 
\text{For the year ended December 31, 2018}\\ \hline 
\begin{array}{l r r }\\ 
\text{Sales} & \$\hspace{7pt}15,301&\\ 
\text{Less: Cost of Sales} & \underline{7,135} & \\ 
\textbf{Gross Profit} & \$\hspace{9pt}8,166\\ 
\text{Less: Depreciation} & \underline{\quad 1,363} &\\ 
\textbf{Earnings before interest and taxes} & \$\hspace{7pt}6,803\\ 
\text{Interest Expense} & \underline{388}\\ 
\textbf{Taxable income} & {{\mathbf{\$\hspace{13pt}6,415}}}\\ 
\text{Tax Expense} & \underline{\hspace{25pt}1,347}\\ 
\textbf{Net income} & \underline{\underline{\mathbf{\$\hspace{13pt}5,068}}}\\ \end{array}\\\\ \hline 
\end{array}$$

Since, we have computed the OCF, Change in NWC and Net Capital Spending, we will now compute the cash flow from assets using the equation in step 11.

$$\begin {array}{lrr} 
\text{Operating Cash Flow}&\$\hspace{10pt}\text{6,819}\\ 
\text{Less: Change in Net Working Capital}&{\text{42}}\\ 
\text{Less: Net Capital Spending}&\underline{\text{2,378}}&\\ 
\textbf{Cash flow from assets}&\underline{\underline{\$\hspace{5pt}\textbf{4,399}}}\\ \end{array}$$


Therefore, the cash flow from assets of Parrothead Enterprises is  **$4,399**.

### d. Cash Flow to Creditors and Long-term Debt Paid off

Cash Flow to Creditors is computed as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Cash Flow to Creditors} &= \text{Interest Paid} - {\text{Net New Borrowings}}\\[1pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Then, since the company had a net new borrowings of $167. We also know that the net new borrowings is equal to debt issued less debt paid off. Hence, to get the debt paid off we will squeeze back the formula:

 $$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Debt Paid off} &= \text{Debt Issued} - {\text{Net New Borrowings}}\\[5pt]
&= \text{\$504} - {\text{167}}\\[5pt]
&= \underline{\underline{\textbf{\$337}}}
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the long-term debt of Parrothead Enterprises that have paid off during the year is **$337**.

Lastly, now that we have computed the net new borrowings , let's now compute for the cash flow to creditors using the equation in step 15.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Cash Flow to Creditors} &= \text{Interest Paid} - {\text{Net New Borrowings}}\\[5pt]
&= \text{\$388} - {\text{167}}\\[5pt]
&= \underline{\underline{\textbf{\$221}}}
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the cash flow to creditor of Kerber's Tennis Shop is **$221**.

In this problem, we are required to determine the ownersâ€™ equity, change in net working capital, fixed assets sold, cash flow from assets, long-term debt paid off, and cash flow to creditors for Parrothead Enterprises.

Before we begin, let us first define cash flow:

**Cash flow** is the net amount of cash and cash equivalents moving in and out of a company during a period of time.

## a. Ownersâ€™ equity for 2017

The formula for owners' equity can be denoted as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Owner's equity}& = \text{Total Assets - Total Liabilities}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

Before we can determine the owners' equity, first we need to determine the total assets:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Current assets}& \$1,206\\
\text{Add: Net fixed assets} & 4,973\\ \hline
\textbf{Total Assets}&\boxed{\$6,179}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Next is to determine the total liabilities:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Current liabilities}& \$482\\
\text{Add: Long-term debt} & 2,628\\ \hline
\textbf{Total Liabilities}&\boxed{\$3,110}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Finally, to determine the owners' equity for 2017:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Owner's equity}& = \text{Total Assets - Total Liabilities}\\ \\
&=\$6,179  -  \$3,110\\ \\
&=\boxed{\$3,069}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the owners' equity for 2017 is $3,069.

## Ownersâ€™ equity for 2018

The formula for owners' equity can be denoted as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Owner's equity}& = \text{Total Assets - Total Liabilities}\\ \\
\end{aligned}$$

Before we can determine the owners' equity, first we need to determine the total assets:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Current assets}& \$1,307\\
\text{Add: Net fixed assets} & 5,988\\ \hline
\textbf{Total Assets}&\boxed{\$7,295}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Next is to determine the total liabilities:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Current liabilities}& \$541\\
\text{Add: Long-term debt} & 2,795\\ \hline
\textbf{Total Liabilities}&\boxed{\$3,336}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Finally, to determine the owners' equity for 2018:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Owner's equity}& = \text{Total Assets - Total Liabilities}\\ \\
&=\$7,295  -  \$3,336\\ \\
&=\boxed{\$3,959}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the owners' equity for 2018 is $3,959.

## b. Change in net working capital for 2018

Before we can determine the changes in net working capital, first we need to determine the net working capital for 2017:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Current Assets}& \$1,206\\
\text{Less: Current Liabilities} &  482\\ \hline
\textbf{Net Working Capital}&\boxed{\$724}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Next is to determine the net working capital for 2018:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Current Assets}& \$1,307\\
\text{Less: Current Liabilities} & 541\\ \hline
\textbf{Net Working Capital}&\boxed{\$766}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Now we can already determine changes in net working capital for 2018:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Net Working Capital, end}& \$766\\
\text{Less: Net Working Capital, beginning} & 724\\ \hline
\textbf{Changes in Net Working Capital}&\boxed{\$42}\\ \\
\end{array}$$
\
In conclusion, the changes in net working capital for 2018 is $42.

## c. Fixed assets sold

Before we can determine the fixed assets sold, first we need to determine the net capital spending:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Net Fixed Assets - 2018}& \$5,988\\
\text{Less: Net Fixed Assets - 2017} & 4,973\\
\text{Add: Depreciation} & 1,363\\  \hline
\textbf{Net Capital Spending}&\boxed{\$2,378}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Finally, to determine the fixed assets sold:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Fixed assets sold}& = \text{Fixed assets bought - Net Capital Spending}\\ \\
&=\$2,496  -  \$2,378\\ \\
&=\boxed{\$118}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, Parrothead Enterprises sold $118 of fixed assets.

## c. Cash flow from assets

Before we can determine the cash flow from assets, first let us prepare an income statement:

$$ 
\bold{Parrothead~Enterprises}\\ 
\bold{Income~Statement}\\ 
\bold{For~ the ~Year~ Ended~ 2018}\\ $$

$$\begin{array}{cccc}\\
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Sales}&&&\text{\$15,301.00}&\\
&\text{Less: Cost of Goods Sold}&&&\text{7,135.00}&\\
&\text{ Depreciation}&&&\underline{\text{~~~~~~~~1,363.00}}&\\
&\text{EBIT}&&&{\$~6,803.00}\\ 
&\text{Less: Interest}&&&\underline{~~~~~~~~~~388.00}&\\
&\text{EBT}&&&6,415.00&\\
&\text{Less: Taxes (21\%)}&&&\underline{~~~~~~~~~~1,347.15}&\\
&\bold{Net~Income}&&&{\boxed{\bold{\$~5,067.85}}}\\

\end{aligned}
\end{array}$$
\
The net income for 2018 is $5,067.85.

Next is to determine the operating cash flow for 2018:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Operating cash flow}& = \text{EBIT + Depreciation - Taxes}\\ \\
&=\$6,803.00 + \$1,363.00 -  \$1,347.15\\ \\
&=\boxed{\$6,818.85}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Finally, to determine the cash flow from assets for the year:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Operating cash flow}& \$6,818.85\\
\text{Less: Net Capital Spending} & 2,378.00\\ 
\text{Less: Changes in Net Working Capital} & 42.00\\ \hline
\textbf{Cash flow from assets}&\boxed{\$4,398.85}\\ \\
\end{array}$$
\
In conclusion, the cash flow from assets for the year is $4,398.85.

## d. Cash flow to creditors

Before we can determine the cash flow to creditors, first we need to determine the net new borrowing:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Long-term debt - 2018}& \$2,795\\
\text{Less: Long-term debt - 2017} & 2,628\\ \hline
\textbf{Net new borrowing}&\boxed{\$167}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

The cash flow to creditors can be computed as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Cash flow to creditors}& = \text{Interest paid - Net new borrowing} \\ \\
&=\$388 - \$167\\ \\
&=\boxed{\$221}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the cash flow to creditors is $221.

Also, to determine the debt retired:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Debt retired}& = \text{Debt issued - Net new borrowing} \\ \\
&=\$504 - \$167\\ \\
&=\boxed{\$337}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the debt retired is $337.
